page.title: 06ECOLOGY
page.content: {Duddingston Loch}was formed 10,000 years ago after the last Ice Age. In 1923 it was given to the nation as a {Bird Sanctuary.}The Scottish Wildlife Trust purchased the neighbouring {Bawsinch Nature Reserve}in 1971 to protect wildlife habitats. { Reed beds}have encroached on the water; other plants have grown on the rotting vegetation, and, as a result of natural succession, trees such as hawthorn have flourished. Eventually a {Climax Woodland}of oak and ash will be reached. The Loch is famous for both{breeding {and wintering wildfowl.}Greylag geese, pochard and coot may be observed. There are 33 species of trees which provide shelter for birds and mammals. Several small ponds have been created to provide habitats for water plants and insect larvae such as damsel fly.
